content.raw:
The [`ign-cmake` PR for `ign-transport`](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/239/use-ign-cmake/diff) is almost ready to merge (but we should for a new release of `ign-cmake` first). If anyone wants to give that PR one last review, now would be a good time.

Once we've released a new `ign-cmake`, we can merge that branch, and then merge its changes back to this branch, and then CI should work again for this branch.
content.html:
The ign-cmake PR for ign-transport is almost ready to merge (but we should for a new release of ign-cmake first). If anyone wants to give that PR one last review, now would be a good time.

Once we've released a new ign-cmake, we can merge that branch, and then merge its changes back to this branch, and then CI should work again for this branch.

content.raw:
Windows is broken because release-tools is still using the old CI pipeline for `ign-transport` while `ign-transport4` depends on `ign-msgs1` which is using the new pipeline.

Finishing the `ign-cmake` branch pull request for `ign-transport` and then updating `release-tools` will fix this. I'm very close to having all of that finished; I just need to resolve some timeouts that are occurring on Windows in some of the `ign-transport` tests.
content.html:
Windows is broken because release-tools is still using the old CI pipeline for ign-transport while ign-transport4 depends on ign-msgs1 which is using the new pipeline.

Finishing the ign-cmake branch pull request for ign-transport and then updating release-tools will fix this. I'm very close to having all of that finished; I just need to resolve some timeouts that are occurring on Windows in some of the ign-transport tests.

Jenkins:

  • Xenial is
  • Homebrew is pending
  • Windows is

Xenial is fixed: https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/100/ with the release of ign-msgs1.

Update to release script: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/499
content.html:

content.raw: Waiting on the windows build machine.

I think we had a miscommunication then. The release branch is created before the release happens, and this could happen at an arbitrary time before the actual release. However, the generation of stable debs and the bumping of a version are independent events.

I reviewed the internal wiki and made the change: "Once an official release branch has been made, bump the version on default's CMakeLists.txt". The keyword "branch" has been inserted.
content.html:
I think we had a miscommunication then. The release branch is created before the release happens, and this could happen at an arbitrary time before the actual release. However, the generation of stable debs and the bumping of a version are independent events.

I reviewed the internal wiki and made the change: "Once an official release branch has been made, bump the version on default's CMakeLists.txt". The keyword "branch" has been inserted.

content.raw:
As someone who builds from source and installs all libraries in the same place, I benefit from having default not colliding with release branches, so I **personally** would also prefer to bump sooner rather than later. If a downstream library explicitly needs the default branch, I think the library should explicitly bump its dependencies.

Having that said, I believe the conclusion from last year's decision was to only bump after the official release (i.e. stable debs), because, among other reasons, the pre-release branch is usually created way before it is even certain that a release will happen.

If we change the rule, we should update the internal wiki:

http://internal.local/New%20version%20release%20process
content.html:
As someone who builds from source and installs all libraries in the same place, I benefit from having default not colliding with release branches, so I personally would also prefer to bump sooner rather than later. If a downstream library explicitly needs the default branch, I think the library should explicitly bump its dependencies.

Having that said, I believe the conclusion from last year's decision was to only bump after the official release (i.e. stable debs), because, among other reasons, the pre-release branch is usually created way before it is even certain that a release will happen.

If we change the rule, we should update the internal wiki:

http://internal.local/New%20version%20release%20process

content.raw:
```otherwise you can't test a release branch along side default```

I assume you mean you can't install a release branch and default with the same `CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX` because they will overwrite each other?
content.html:
otherwise you can't test a release branch along side default

I assume you mean you can't install a release branch and default with the same CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX because they will overwrite each other?

content.raw:
The rule is to bump the version on default when a release branch is created, not when the release debian is produced.

Bumping the version on default is a mandatory activity, otherwise you can't test a release branch along side default. I believe we discussed all of this before Christmas break, and agreed upon this pattern.
content.html:
The rule is to bump the version on default when a release branch is created, not when the release debian is produced.

Bumping the version on default is a mandatory activity, otherwise you can't test a release branch along side default. I believe we discussed all of this before Christmas break, and agreed upon this pattern.

content.raw:
Bumping it on default adds an annoyance either when building all ignition projects on default branch, or when building just one project using apt to install transport. To build all from default every ignition project depending on transport has to depend on transport5. Doing that breaks builds using the apt-repo though, so they really need to be made to accept 4 or 5. In the meantime one of those kinds of builds is broken until that happens.

If default is left at 4 then both ways of building work for as long as the two major versions are source-compatible.
content.html:
Bumping it on default adds an annoyance either when building all ignition projects on default branch, or when building just one project using apt to install transport. To build all from default every ignition project depending on transport has to depend on transport5. Doing that breaks builds using the apt-repo though, so they really need to be made to accept 4 or 5. In the meantime one of those kinds of builds is broken until that happens.

If default is left at 4 then both ways of building work for as long as the two major versions are source-compatible.

content.raw:
I think that the main issue which has been [brought up before](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/235/4-default/diff#comment-49474101) was homebrew needing a new formula.

And to complement what @mxgrey said, actually everyone building default right now thinks it is ign-transport3. For example, Gazebo default can be built against ign-transport default [thinking it is 3](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/235/4-default/diff#comment-52081450).
content.html:
I think that the main issue which has been brought up before was homebrew needing a new formula.

And to complement what @mxgrey said, actually everyone building default right now thinks it is ign-transport3. For example, Gazebo default can be built against ign-transport default thinking it is 3.

content.raw: It would cause some issues for any CI pipelines that try to fetch `default` while assuming that it'll provide `ign-transport4`. But that's probably more of an issue with our CI setup than with the concept of bumping the major version on default before a stable release.
content.html: It would cause some issues for any CI pipelines that try to fetch default while assuming that it'll provide ign-transport4. But that's probably more of an issue with our CI setup than with the concept of bumping the major version on default before a stable release.

content.raw: If the version is not bumped on default, then default will overwrite ign-transport4. Is there a particular problem that occurs if the version is bumped?
content.html: If the version is not bumped on default, then default will overwrite ign-transport4. Is there a particular problem that occurs if the version is bumped?

content.raw: windows and xenial jenkins builds fail to find ignition-msgs1
content.html: windows and xenial jenkins builds fail to find ignition-msgs1

content.raw: I had understood we would only bump default after a stable release
content.html: I had understood we would only bump default after a stable release

content.raw: Looking good. All tests passed locally, waiting on the other test results here.
content.html: Looking good. All tests passed locally, waiting on the other test results here.

content.raw: I'm also bumping the version number on default to 5 to avoid conflict with ign-transport4.
content.html: I'm also bumping the version number on default to 5 to avoid conflict with ign-transport4.
